Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 05:10PM bettelou68 wrote: I am having SNB next Monday, and planning to return to work as soon as I safely can. Just how sore is the incision for this? Will I have trouble raising my arm. And it never occurred to me that I might have a drain. I have heard so much about those drains, that even the thought of one bothers me.
Posts.Title: Drain with SNB? MinAZ emath

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 10:59AM bettelou68 wrote: I had SNB two days ago, and am back at work today with a pillow cushioning my armpit. I was going to try it without the pain meds, but gave in and took them mid-morning. I am finding that lifting or stretching out my arm is uncomfortable. I had to drive this morning and I was fine as long as I didn't have to turn. I am going to ask my surgeon for exercises to stretch out this arm. right now I am doing most tasks with my other hand. I had two nodes out. Preliminary examination said they were OK. Waiting for full path report. You never realize how sensitive an armpit can be! Until!
Posts.Title: Anyone with severe SNB Pain? Knives in armpit! Keryl morning

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 02:28PM bettelou68 wrote: Having only been a metster  for six weeks, I draw strength an encouragement and advice from this board. I do not want to be told about how I can be "cured" by snake blood or diet, supplements, etc. I feel like it is too late for that now. What is not too late is to take part in this clinical trial to help future metsters. I may not ever be NED. I may not ever hold grandbabies or celebrate my 5th wedding anniversary. But I can move this new drug out on the market to help others and pay it forward to help others as I have been helped. Bette

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 07:11AM bettelou68 wrote: Misty, I am feeling almost like you. Breakfast I can do, but the rest of the time I have no interest in  eating. My weight is down 7 pounds in three days, so I have to figure out a solution. Veterans? Suggestions? Bette

Posts.Content: bettelou68 wrote: As part of my clinical trial, I get gemzar/carboplatin two weeks on, then one week off. I just got my third infusion and have been told that my ALT and AST are triple the normal levels and that they can't treat me this week, and maybe not next week either. Along the way, I developed pneumonia this week as well as high blood sugar. So the oncs are saying rest, and I am imagining my lung mets growing, growing growing. I am afraid of having to drop out of the trial. I just got diagnosed with Stage IV in July 2009, and Gem/Carb is my first line treatment. I don't know where to go from here.  Has anyone else had elevated liver enzymes with Gem/Carb? Did they resolve?  www.caringbridge.org/visit/bettedietrick "Yet in all these things, we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us."Romans 8:37 Dx 8/20/2008, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

I've been reading all your posts, and really appreciate all the good info. I will be traveling for surgery and staying with my daughter and husband until my post-op visit.  Pamela, you say to listen to the PS and take notes. I am meeting my PS for the first time on 1/30. What questions should I be sure I have answers to before I leave his office? Bette

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 02:15PM bettelou68 wrote:
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 07:11AM bettelou68 wrote: Feeling much better after taking that first shower! The exercises were challenging, but I was gentle with myself and got through them with minimal pain. Manay gals have told me that they skipped those exercises and later regretted it because they were stiff after healing. So I decided to start on time. I am making a chart for myself to check off that I did them every day. My skin is itching everywhere, especially under this surgical bra. I just finished slathering on body lotion everywhere but the area where that drains come out. That feels much better! This whole mx experience is more doable than I expected. The challenging part is going to be finding a wedding dress for my March 28 wedding with my reivented cleavage. Everything I like seems to be cut so low! I guess I will have to just go try on a bunchj. DD is coming with me to make sure I don't make any grave fashion errors! Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 07:09AM bettelou68 wrote: Francine, my prayers are with you! Love, Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 01:00PM bettelou68 wrote: Received good pathology report today. Clean margins, no lymph node, nipple or skin involvement.  Lots of stuff about tumor markeers and grade which I did not fully undeersdatnd. I will read up on this this week to prepare for a planning appointment with my onc on Monday, 2-2 This is where I should find out about furtheeer treatment like beginning of rads. Francine, How are you How did it go. Tom  and I both saw my incision yesterday. He was gentle and accepting and supportive. It is not smoth and flat as I thought it would be, rather curved, with extra tissue at each end, and about the curve of a 12 year old girl. I am going ahead with wedding plans and have made an appointment with David´s Bridal for February 21 . Two months until the wedding Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 04:25PM bettelou68 wrote: I made the drive to Baltimore this evening. Staying with DD and going to have fluid drained from my chest at Hopkins tomorrow AM. It seems that drain was not ready to come out! I pray that the fluid does not come back as that may require more long trips to have it drained, or even the insertion of a new surgical drain. I was not able to have my radiation simulatiion this morning due to the instability the fluid is causing in my chest. I look like I have a B cup where it is supposed to be flat! Everything is stalled until the fluid problem is solved. Oh, well. I know that God has a plan in this. I just don´t know what will happen at this point. Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 04:01PM bettelou68 wrote: The fluid, all 200 cc´s of it, is gone, and my scar looks very wrinkled after being stretched so tight. I am under ordeers to wear a very tight sports bra to compress things and keep it from coming back. The procedure was not too bad, and there was even a Hopkins Breast Center volunteer to hold my hand. I drove back to DD´s in a snowstorm and took a 4 hour nap. Will drive back to PA tomorrow. Saturday is wedding dress day with an appointment at a bridal shop. I am now weaaaring a beautiful engagement ring. I love the ring, but I appreciate more Tom´s love, and how hard he worked to pay for the ring. He presented it to me on Valentine´s Day. It´s back to Baltimore next Tuesday for a recheck, so I am praying for no more drainage so that they won´t haave to reinsert the surgical drain. Try hiding THAT undeeer a wedding gown! Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 10:15AM bettelou68 wrote: The swelling is back Now I have to wait until Tuesday to discover my fate! On the bright side, I found a wedding dress that covers my port scar and my Mx scar. But it doesn't have a drain pocket LOL Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 01:01PM bettelou68 wrote: I want to thank all of you who replied to my "when to look at the incision" question. I believe I will use a mirror at first. My fiance' is a nurse, so I will let him check it for infection. Only 5 days to go. A nurse case manager called from my health insurance company. He says he will ok as many nights as I need, plus home care if I want it and my doctor writes for it. I will be alone during the day while DD and her husband are at work. Would it be a good idea to have someone check in on me?  Has anyone else had home care visits, and what is your opinion? I guess this is really going to happen. I took a "before" picture of my boobs yesterday. The left one with the inflammatory breast cancer in it looks red and angry and diseased(and huge) in the picture. It is time to part ways with that breast, do rads and get on with my life. Our wedding is still scheduled for March 28, rads or not. We are planning to go away that weekend, and take a longer honeymoon when I am fully recovered from rads. So one way to look at this is that I get TWO honeymoons out of the situation. Wedding arrangements:caterer, cake, flowers, photography, music, invitations, are complete. One missing item is THE DRESS, which I will not shop for until I see what kind of body I have to put in it. I know it will not be a low-cut garment. Just have to see what is available off the rack. Francine, I will be praying for your mastectomy to heal so that you do not need more surgery. Thank you for starting this thread. It has been an encouragement to me. HotandCold, I too have had chemo and am bald and scarred( I have incisions already from port placement and SNB, and soon the Mx scar). I will not know if I need more chemo until I get the pathology report from surgery. I do know that rads are in my immediate future. I have decided to handle it one day at a time. Each day I try to schedule something pleasant, so that I don't feel as if the whole day was wrapped up in cancer. Today I met someone at a diner for coffee and pastry. I put on nice clothes and all my "Look Good, Feel Better" makeup that I got for free at the ACS workshop. I felt like a normal woman joining a friend for coffee. When I have to stay in, I make time for reading a good book, seeing a funny movie, doing my nails, or  something to pamper myself. I know these activities will be limited for a time after the surgery, but I'll sneak them in as soon as possible, because it is too depressing for me to look at all the cancer treatments stretching out into my future. One day I can handle.  Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 04:14PM bettelou68 wrote: It's time to start packing for Baltimore. My surgery is at the Sydney Kimmel Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins on Tuesday, January 20. I can watch inauguration reruns when I get to my room. Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 02:19PM bettelou68 wrote: Gayle I just came back from my first drive since surgery, over 3 weeks ago. I was in my local hospital with suspected blood clots and a chest infection  for the past three days, and my doctor from Hopkins called and arranged for a surgeon here to remove the drain, so I am free! My hair is coming in thick and half gray on top, my usual black and slightly longer on the sides. I have no idea when rads is to start. First appointment with rads onc is next Tuesday for 3 hours! What are they going to do to me all that time? I am still wearing my post-surgical bra. If I am going to church or out somewhere, I wear a puff, but around the  house and for errands I go flat. Much more comfortable. I have two post-surgical camisoles, and they are comfy, but the PS wants me in this bra for some reason. I'm afraid I neglected the exercises while I was hospitalized. Now they are harder to do. I really noticed the tightness when I had to turn or back the car today. I will have to call work soon and arrange to return. I am reluctant, as my job is very stressful, and I am still so tired. I may not have a job after all as I was not there long enough to be covered by the FMLA. Well time to make dinner. Take care of yourself. Bette
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 05:21PM bettelou68 wrote: I had DD A/C every two weeks on Wednesday, which was my day off because I worked 10 hour days. Thursdays I was fine, but by Friday, Neulasta shot day, I was exhausted, had chills and was running to the ladies room every half hour. The weekend was a washout, and Monday and Tuesday were marginal as far as production at work. I was new on the job and so didn't have much time off built up yet. My productivity slipped so much that I eventually got a written warning. After four A/C I switched to DD Taxol/Neulasta every two weeks. On day 4 after Taxol, I spiked a 103 fever and was hospitalized for a week. the same thing happened after the second Taxol. I have had to take short term disability and am not sure I will have a job when I get back since I am too new for the FMLA to cover me. My onc switched me to Taxotere every three weeks. I had the first treatment today and am waiting to see what my SE's will be. Prior to this I was a healthy woman, age 53. Now I feel really worn out, but only one chemo to go, and my tumor is almost gone.  My story is not so good, but it can happen. I know other people who have worked through chemo just fine. I pray that you will too.  Bette

Due to pain, I still take the narcotics from time to time, but  am trying to transition to Advil. Another reason not to drive. If this drain ever quits draining, it can be removed and life can get back to normal. I am getting married on March 28 and hope to be drainless by then. Next step for me is rads. Bette

It didn't hurt going in, but I can feel it pulling under my arm when I move. I had to drive today and it was uncomfortable. A good thing is that there is no infection. They have me on antibiotics, just to be safe. Bette

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 04:22AM bettelou68 wrote: Gayleeee, Congrats on getting back to work! I have been out since October 27 between chemo complications and surgery. Hope to be back in early March. I am not doing PT, but am trying to be faithful with my arm exercises, although they sometimes hurt.  I had my nuclear shots the day of surgery. Right through the nipple. Ouch. It was over quick, but while it lasted hurt more than the surgery. It was worth it though, because they were able to remove only 4 nodes, AND they were clear. So far, I do not have more chemo in my future, but I do have rads starting soon, then tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor for 5 years.  I pray for complete and fast recovery for all of us who have recently had surgery. I am still not driving after three weeks due to pain meds and this pesky drain.  Bette

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 10:43AM bettelou68 wrote: Lyn, How wonderful that your surgery is now behind you, and that your tow lymph nodes look good. How are you feeling? Do you have anyone who speaks English to talk with, or just not any that have had bc. I just had a sentinel lymph node biopsy last week, and will hear on Wednesday if the nodes are negative for sure. As in your case, they did not appear to be involved. I am back at work and getting over my surgical soreness. What kind of surgery did you have? Lumpectomy? How is your daughter doing with this? I have a 24 year old daughter that I got to see get married last year, and it is the most touching experience. You sound like you are in good hands, and I am confident that you will get there too. I have a > 4 cm IDC that they are going to try to shrink with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, so that I may be able to have a lumpectomy. Right now, my breast, though large, is so involved with the tumor that I would have to have a mastectomy followed by chemo and radiation, so no reconstruction until that would be all over. I have never thought about traveling to another country for care. I drive two hours from a small town to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore, and their breast center is tops. Plus they speak English. I speak German very well. Wish I could be there to translate for you.! Take care. and stay connected. There are so many of us here that have been through it and are willing to chat. Bette

Posts.Content: bettelou68 wrote: Since I started chemo back in August 2008, I have been getting letters and cards of support and even packages from some wonderful volunteers. They are part of the Chemo Angels network, which matches cancer patients with people who encourage them with weekly mail. I got engaged recently, and so far have received 12 cards of congratulations from Angels all over the country. To register with Chemo Angels and be matched with a volunteer to support you by mail while you are in treatment, go to www.chemoangels.com. Chemo can be tough. Evry bit of encouragement helps you on this part of your cancer journey. Bette  www.caringbridge.org/visit/bettedietrick "Yet in all these things, we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us."Romans 8:37 Dx 8/20/2008, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 07:31AM bettelou68 wrote: I have now received close to 30 engagement cards from Chemo Angels. Many of them are handmade, and they are all beautiful. These women are talented and compassionate. Remember, if you, or someone you know is down because of SE's and fatigue, try signing up for your very own Angel. It really lifts your spirits to get cheerful cards of encouragement and support. I found that the cards tended to arrive on my worst days, when I really needed to hear from someone. www.chemoangels.com

Posts.Title: Good News Irina hollyann

Posts.Content: bettelou68 wrote: On Monday, July 27 2009, I received a phone call that my lung biopsy is positive for IBC mets.  On Wednesday, July 29 I have an appointment with a renowned oncologist at a major cancer center to develop a treatment plan. What should I be asking this doc? What happens next? I am so scared. After rads I thought I had beat IBC. Now it is back. Posts.Title: Where do I go from here? bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 06:35PM bettelou68 wrote: I am doing neoadjuvant chemo to shrink my tumor, too. My surgeon placed a "clip" in the tumor at the time of my SNB. Supposedly this will help locate the tumor in the happy event that chemo makes it disappear. But maybe she will need to do a wire-guided lumpectomy. Does the wire hurt as much as an SNB injection? THAT took me by surprise. More painful than I expected, but at least it was over quickly. Bette
Posts.Title: Wire guided lumpectomy? mommy3abm KAK

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 02:49PM bettelou68 wrote: Thanks for the info about the clip placement. I talked to my boss today and now have a backup plan for if I need another day off. I am going to play it by ear. I am taking a supportive, front -close bra with me to wear home. And a front closing blouse to wear over that. Even now it is uncomfortable to raise my arm on the side of the tumor due to an infection I have in my biopsied breast so I thought I would stay away from any over-the head styles. First-aid tape gives me blisters, so I will be sure and tell them about that. What else do I need to remember?  Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 03:14PM bettelou68 wrote: I am now home from the hospital with a sore armpit, head swimming from general anesthesia and hydrocodone. They decided not to put the port in because I still had an infection in my breast, and infection going into a central vein would be bad news. I will rest tonight at my daughter's and sometime tomorrow make the drive back to PA for my MUGA scan Now I have to make time off work after the infection clears to get the port put in. My boss will be not be happy, but what can I do?  The outpatient surgery staff and Dr. Lisa Jacobs at Johns Hopkins were super. Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 12:06PM bettelou68 wrote: Now that I have read everyone's comments, I am going to negotiate for Tuesday off. Another Q. What kind of anesthesia did you have for your SNB? Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 07:11AM bettelou68 wrote: Well tomorrow is surgery day. I am off to drive to Baltimore to stay with my daughter the night before. We are going out for Chinese food tonight to take my mind off things. As it turns out I have my MUGA scan on Tuesday, so have a good excuse not to work that day. Will it hurt to lift the arm on the SNB side initially? How about driving? Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 07:13PM bettelou68 wrote: Well, Now I can answer my original question. Working the day after surgery was not "doable" at least for me. I spent the day in bed on pain pills. Today I bravely went off to work, a small pillow under my arm to prevent rubbing. I still found that the incision pulled and burned, although I was trying to do everything right-handed. Tonight it feels a bit better, so I am encouraged. Port placement is next Wednesday in the "Interventional Radiology " department. Not looking forward to it, but hoping that my left side will be feeling a lot better before the right side gets "attacked" According to what I have been told, I will be awake for the port placement. Yuck. Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 07:25AM bettelou68 wrote: Jule, What tape are you talking about? Do they use it to close the incision? Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 06:06PM bettelou68 wrote: I emailed the surgeon's nurse, and learned that I will be having general anesthesia, so no driving 2 hours home that night. They said I could drive the next morning, so I will leave early, and get to work when I get there. My immediate supervisor is being pretty understanding now. I have to stop worrying about these things. If the sentinel node is positive, how soon do you know? Do they tell you in recovery, Or do you have to wait a few days. It will be hard to wait, as the course of my treatment is hanging on this. Bette
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: bettelou68 wrote: I have a SNB scheduled for a Monday and my boss wants me to come back and work 4 10-hour days to make up the time. I didn't complain as I am new there and have no time off to speak of, but now I am wondering. Is this doable? I have a sedentary data entry type job. I am right-handed, and my surgery will be on my left side. I am afraid of losing my job and insurance if I can't put in the time. I am so glad that this SNB ill not be on my "keying" arm. I will try for a second day though.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 03:25PM bettelou68 wrote: I have to report to Nuclear Medicine at 6:15 AM. I am only having the SNB. They are doing it prior to neoadjuvant chemo so they know if the node is negative or positive. Apparently once chemo has begun it is hard to tell. They are also placing a "clip" in the tumor so it can be found after the chemo (hopefully) shrinks it. I have no idea what that involves. Anyone?
